text: Różnice między 12-stką subtelne. W zapachu bardziej wyraźna beczka. W zapachu bardziej kwaśne, goryczka troszkę wyższa, posmak bardziej palony.
Bottle a black colored beer with a white head aroma malts chocolate coffee oak spicy caramel and porto flavor malts chocolate dark fruits coffee dried fruits oak caramel spicy and some bitterness

Bottle from Voldby. Pours black with a beige head. Aroma and taste is malt, dark chocolate, coffee, caramel, whiskey notes, dark fruits. Medium body. Soft carbonation. Oily mouthfeel. Light bitter finish.

Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks kerenmk. Deep brown with a beige head. Aroma of oak, peat, iodine, chocolate, port wine, whiskey. Sweet, roasted, chocolate, caramel, peat, wood, moderate bitterness. Full-bodied, oily. Really good.

Bottle sample at a tasting at zvsns place. Thanks keremk. Deep brownish-amber with beige head. The aroma has some peat, whiskey, ink, alcoholic and smoked. Bitterish flavor, alcoholic with notes of ink, peat, quite oily, wood, some smokiness, alcohol warmth in the finish. Full-bodied.

Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of roast, Barrel, deep toffee, tar, loads whisky, smoke - peat?, notes of bandaid. Heavy sweet, loads of dry barrel, smoke, vinous, dried fruits, phenolic like smoke, bandaid.

Black color, small brown head. Aromas of toffee, caramel, wood, whisky, chocolate, cream, vanilla and dates. Taste of caramel, dates, wood, whisky, malt, chocolate, syrup and dried figs. Sweet and balanced.
UPDATED: MAY 25, 2017 Bottle 330 ml from an Amazon order. Light brown/beige head and black body. Well rounded taste with roasted coffee, caramel and smoky whisky. Rich.

Bottle
Aroma-caramel, whiskey
Appearance-black, hazy, tan foam, 
Taste-light sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, 
Palate-medium body, creamy, average carbonation, long finish, 
Overall-very good

Black color. Thin , brown head. Malt , milk chocolate and whiskey in aroma. Taste follows. Roasted bitterness at the end. Warming finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Black. Huge whiskey presence, whiskey malty, barrely, roasty too though, roasty, light ashy. Fullish bodied, light oily. Yeasty stress. Feels like an impy with manhandled yeast. Which has been thrown in a whiskey barrel. Feels messy unbalanced. Surprisingly easy though.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone

Aged 4 years in the bottle. Inky black hue with no head. Nice nose of woody dates and earthy malts with a sweet darkness about it. Big rich earthy dark flavor with cocoa and woody tones with gentle scotch note and light dates and dark fruits. Smooth whiskeyed non-boozy finish.

Bottle. Whisky aroma. Dark Brown-to-Black in colour. Very Malty; roast/burnt malts, chocolate, coffee, caramel, toffee, vanilla, oak. Whisky taste; smoky, peaty, salty, oily, tarry, iodine. Very Smoky. Fruity; vinous, dark fruits. Viscous. Warming alcohol. Sweet roast malty. Dry bitter roast finish. Lingering smoky aftertaste. More intense flavours than the 12 year old. Very tasty. Enjoyed this a lot. Very Nice Old Ale! (2009)

From a beerhawk mystery case. Pours deep black. Low carbonation. A lovely milk stout , so very nice for a change. Very smooth and velvety. Superb whisky undertones. Leaves you thinking that you have had a new CEO malt whisky. Brilliant. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Refrigerated 11.2 oz. brown bottle poured into a snifter. Black with small dark brown highlights and small beige head. Aroma is nice scotch, medium body, low carbonation, and a little lacing. Taste is dark chocolate, scotch, and some tobacco.

Wonderful aromas of dark chocolate, dark coffee, laktris, oak and whiskey. The flavor is similar but with more flavor of oak and whiskey. Exquisite bitterness that fills the mouth forever. Fabulous beer if you like whiskey and oak barrels. Follow me @ Kung av öl @ Facebook for more pictures and ratings.

Sort Old Ale med fin mindre moccafarvet skumtop på 1-2 cm, som svinder til et par mm. Ufiltreret og rolig i glasset. 
"Sjov" aroma af kældernoter og lidt mug. Desuden egetræ og senere klare whiskynoter. 
Smagen er præget af ristet malt og noter af whisky (Highland Park) samt egetræ. Vel afbalanceret med middel bitterhed og lille til middel sødme. 
Elegant blød mundfølelse qua en nedjusteret og veltilpasset karbonering. Konsistensen er olieret til cremet og kroppen er middel fyldig. Afslutningen er bitter og kort. 
Overall: Black Oil var tilfældigvis det tidligere navn til denne gode Scotch Ale, som er krævende, men forholdsvis drikkelig og tro mod de 8.0 %. Harvieston forstår sig på at lave denne slags øl, mærker man. 
330 ml, flaske, 8.0 % ABV, BB: 02/2019, købt i Salt Horse Bottleshop i Edinburgh. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
More tobacco and leather than the lost and found section of a biker bar. Some roast amd light caramel. Black pour with decent head. Oily consistency. Bitter amd slightly tangy finish. Bottle.
2007 bottle. Pours cola brown with aroma of vanilla, dark fruit,molasses, and wood. No carbonation with roasted malt vanilla, dark fruit flavor with hint of booze. Very nice!

Flasche (33 cl) vom Bierzwerg. - Tiefes Schwarzbraun, fast schaumlos. - In der Nase schweres dunkles Malz, Mokka, Karamel und zarte Noten von Vanillezucker und Torf. - Antrunk schwer und füllig röstmalzig mit kräftigem Mokka und verhaltener Süße, die sich mit den torfig-aschigen Noten reibt. Mild rezent, glatt trotz Schwere. Im Abgang Bitterschokolade und kernige Noten von Asche (oder Rauch) und Whisky. - Interessantes, zweifellos auch besonderes Bier, aber es hinterläßt keinen so starken Eindruck wie vor einem Jahr das 12er. Ob das jetzt am Bier liegt oder am verflossenen Jahr - wer weiß ...
Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer.

From bottle at Fermentoren Aarhus. Pours a clear dark brown with a small off white head. Aroma has lots of the same toffee, tobacco and oaky notes as the 12y, but more vinous, more tannic and woody. Taste is sweet, fruity, some chocoate, rather bitter. Full body and a low carbonation.

Btl 2009. Brune très foncé. Belle mousse beige. Belle texture. Sucré. Bien malté. Caramel/toffee. Café doux. Chocolat au lait. Mélasse. Légèrement terreux. Peu de barrique. Un peu fumé. On goûte le whisky quand même. Finale épicé et cacaoté. Excellente même si la date de péremption indique 2012. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Świetny aromat, owocowy głównie śliwka, jest słodko, karmelowo, waniliowo, jest lekki przyjemny alkohol. W smaku slodko, palono, wanilowo, alkohol bardzo dobrze ukryty.
Bottle. Black with hardly any head. Full bodied yet surprisingly smooth. Slightly fruity with some wooden flavours thrown in. Powerful but not threatening. An excellent beer.

Aroma:

Medium aroma of malts, caramel, wood, vanilla, chocolate, roasted malts and peat.

Appearance:

Opaque black beer with a slight/medium brown head.

Taste/Palate:

Starts medium sweet with malts, caramel, wood, vanilla and chocolate; ends slightly bitter and dry with roasted malts and peat.

Overall:

This beer is intense, complex and balanced. Old Ales from this brewery are always so extremely complex, amazing to behold. Great flavour thanks to this. The aroma could have been stronger, but that ia the only real flaw.

Arômes de vanille et légères notes de whisky herbal. Robe noire, faible mousse beige éphémère. En bouche, très puissant: grain torréfié, vanille, chocolat, liquoreux et légère amertume. Carbonation moyenne.

Bottle. Teku. Pitch black with tiny, light brown head. Very poor head retention and average lacing. Nice, medium aroma of cocoa nibs, milk chocolate, lightly coffee and dried fruits notes. Aroma is also empowered with light to medium caramel notes, slightly ashy. Taste is semi-dry to semi-bitter, rather constant thru the whole of degustation. Medium body, creamy and semi-thick texture, soft carbonation, finish is semi-dry and cocoa, slightly ABV warming. In general good beer with nice and pleasant nose and taste, aint fireworks, but worth trying.

Noire dencre, petit collet fuyant
Aromes riches et complexes, reglisse, café, vanille, bois, légères notes de whisky tourbé.
Le boisé ressort bien plus une fois en bouche, mais on retrouve aussi tous les aromes. La finale manque juste un poil de présence sur la longueur.
Carbo en bouche assez calme et douce

Jet black with beige foamy head disappearing quickly, nice lacing though. Milk chocolate, toffee, vanilla and licorice in aroma. Quite sweet, milk chocolate, toffee flavours. Low carbonation. Enjoyed it thoroughly :)
330ml bottle. Impenetrable black with a foamy tan head that mostly fizzed away quite quickly. Sweet, peat smoke aroma. Flavour is coffee, chocolate, smoke and quite dry in the finish. Excellent

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2016 At a tasting, many thanks, almost no head, pitch black color, flavor of biltong dried beer and dark sourdough bread with oxidsed and coffee hints in the back, flavor of chocolate, ash and charred wood with hints of vanila, prunes and halva. Really mellow and highly enjoyable.

Caramel, chocolate, peat, whiskey in nose. Pours very dark brown with beige head. Taste is sweet with caramel, peat, chocolate. Low bitter finish, medium body. Overall good but slightly disappointing, especially body is too thin.
zwart met een beschieden bruine kraag. Geur van turf en gevriesdroogde koffie, smaak vooral as en koffie met suiker. had hier zelf iets meer van verwacht.

Ink black, ruby highlights. Moderate tan head. Bubbly lacing. Nose: barrel, oak, iodine, peat. Medium to full body. Oily. Complex taste with notes mentioned for aroma. Light bitterness. Not as extreme as the 18 years version. In my opinion at least not worse than the latter.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone

A smokey malt aroma, with a hint of whiskey and wood. Pours a black color without much head. A nice smokey malt taste, with a hint whiskey and soy sauce. Body is lighter than you would expect with a slightly watery smoked malt finish.

A 16 éves verzió került sorra, s mint whisky hordóban érlelődött sör, már eleve izgalmas darabnak ígérkezik, az évszám emelkedése ez esetben egyenes arányos lehet a minőség fokával, gondolhatnánk. Közepes teste már a kitöltés során felfedezhető, illatai azonban masszívak, teltek, érettek; marcipános, likőrös, vaníliás single malt aromák, amikhez kissé éles váltással társul a későbbiek során a markánsabb, tőzeges lecsengés, de ne szaladjunk ennyire előre. A test, ahogyan arra számítottunk, enyhén szellős, közepesen szénsavas, mázsás súlytól mentes, vagy legalábbis a hordóban ázott ízjegyek lakhelyeként kissé szűkösnek tekinthető, mégis elegáns, könnyed, de teljes értékű. A csúcspont természetesen a Highland Park hordó által biztosított füstös vonalak, amelyek a levezetés fő irányát képviselik, az előzmények alapján némiképpen váratlanul, de korántsem rendszeridegen módon, a whisky ismeretének fényében legalábbis semmiképpen, csupán az alapok lehettek volna masszívabbak, hogy a struktúra némiképp vaskosabb lábakon álljon, s az efféle betetőzést megingathatatlanul viselje. Igaz azonban, hogy az idő ez esetben is remekül gyúrja egybe a komponenseket, egyre simább és kifogástalan, igen emlékezetes karaktert hagyva maga után.

Bottle- pours jet black with a tan head. Aroma is malt, soy sauce, sherry and roast malt. Taste is smokey and malty up front with a dry malty finish with hint of the whiskey and sea weed. Palate is oily and smooth.

Bottle. Rich caramel and dark fruit aroma. Dark porter like appearance with virtually no head. Flavours present are roasted coffee, dark chocolate, toffee and fruit. Some hints of whisky. Slick and oily texture. Rich malt finish.

Piany kompletnie brak. W aromacie troszkę toffi, może wpada w truflę, w tle obecna jest też whisky. Nasycenie średnie w stronę niskiego, subtelne. W smaku jest trochę słodowej słodczy, toffi, sporo orzechów włoskich. Całość kompozycji kończy się subtelnym akcentem whisky. Nie jakiś alkohol, nie taniny, ani drewno, po prostu subtelny, miękki posmak whisky. Oczywiście alkoholu brak. Gdybym koniecznie miał tu znaleźć jakąś wadę, to po dłuższym zastanowieniu powiedziałbym, że może nico brakuje mu ciała. Klasa sama w sobie, jeżeli chodzi o umiejętność użycia beczki. Nie sposób powiedzieć, gdzie zaczynają się aromaty pochodzące od słodu, a gdzie te od beczki - a prawda jest taka, że w tym piwie przenikają się i grają razem, dając nam świetny finalny efekt.

Bottiglia 5209, giugno 2014, aperta l11 settembre 2016.
Rossa talmente scura da sembrare nera, limpida con riflessi caramello, schiuma nocciola chiara appiccicosa e di persistenza media, medio-bassa.
Aroma affumicato, torba, legno, uva passa, zucchero caramellato, sciroppo dacero, leggera liquirizia.
Al palato affumicata e legnosa, torbata, caffè molto molto leggero, finale legnoso e torbato molto piacevole arricchito da note di cacao amaro, nocciola tostata ed una lievissima punta acidula di frumento.
Corpo medio-pieno, carbonazione bassa, vellutata.

Deep black, small head.
Taste coffee, berries,roasted malt. 
The finish leaves something that reminds me of whisky, some woody, peaty, boozy taste.

Zapach intensywny, wanilia, kawa, torf, beczka, czekolada, karmel, suszone owoce, whisky. Kolor czarny, nieprzejrzyste. Piana beżowa, średnio obfita, drobna, trwała, zdobi szkło. W smaku umiarkowana słodycz, średnia pełnia, torf, kawa, wanilia, whisky, beczka. Goryczka niska, wysycenie niskie.

Bottle. Dark brown with a dark tan scum on top. Nose is vanilla and cedarwood. A little whisky. Taste is woody, burnt, toffee, a touch of whisky, cream, chocolate. Incredibly rich.Raisins and roasted fruit. Theres bags of flavour in this. Nice and sweet, without being sicky. A little slick in the mouth, but not uncomfortable. DELICIOUS!

Piana beżowa, drobna i obfita, trwała i zdobiąca szkło. Barwa ciemno brązowa, nieprzejrzysta. Aromat dość intensywnie waniliowy, do tego oczywiście karmel, suszone owoce, melasa, dębina, whisky i nieco torfu. W smaku podobnie, półsłodkie, treściwe, tu torf nieco wyraźniejszy, sporo kawy, wanilii, likieru. Goryczka niska, palono tytoniowa, lekka szorstkość popiołowa na języku. Wysycenie niskie, pełne, gęste i aksamitne w odbiorze.
W moim odczuciu najlepsze z dotychczas degustowanych Ola Dubh na blogu. Najwyraźniej czuć tu wpływ beczki oraz fajne torfowe smaczki, co przy ogólnej wysokiej jakości piwa dają dodatkowo sporo przyjemności w piciu.
Czuć różnicę pomiędzy tym piwem, a 18-ką. I to na korzyść tego drugiego. Ogólnie piwo jest wyjątkowo przyjemne i udane.
330 ml bottle. Dark brown nearly black. Tan head and some lacing. Roasted taste with chocolate and some coffee.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2017 Harviestoun Brewery by Ola Dubh 16 Year Special ReserveRami Rami is drinking an Ola Dubh 16 Year Special Reserve by Harviestoun Brewery at PowiśleNieco wedzone ogniskowo, beczka i whiski ewidentne, melasa, czekolada, palonosc, wanilia, wisniowe posmaki, oleiste, waniliowe, klasaOcena potraktowana skryptem do przeliczania ocen (uzgodnienie UT/RB).

Un-Muzzling Olde Muzzlehatch Ratings, #8. Bottle from...somewhere...sampled in January, 2009, Burlington VT, starting out at cellar temperature, in a Maudite glass. Deep, near-opaque walnut in color, with a darkish, small beige head that recedes fairly quickly, leaving a bit of residue...the aroma is deep as well, oaky-caramel, aged soft whisky and gracious with light hints of nuts and blueberries...the boozy character is stronger on the palate, sherry alongside whisky, vanilla mixing with fortified grapes and a tart, tannic acidity near the end...the alcohol is rather forward throughout though I would not say overwhelming...the finish has a sharpness that is a bit rough, almost unpleasant, and takes a while to go away, though I will say this improved in the 45 minutes it took me to drink it.
Bottle from LeeAVFC cheers mate; dark opaque brown pour thin light tan head, aroma has rich chocolate, taste has a hint of vanilla, chocolate, some spirit, some vanilla, quite nice.

Aroma: roasted dark malts, bitter chocolate, peated. Appearance: black color and beige head. Taste: low herbal bitterness, bitter chocolate, peated, bonfire, smoked notes, burnt malt, quite dry. Palate: medium body and medium carbonation, peated finish. Overall: It is a really good stuff, amazing peated notes, smooth and complex.

**Copied

bot.no.09957 oct.2012 to may.2016
Gęste, czarne, piana beżowa średnia i drobna, tylko obrączka. Aromat kawa, czekolad, wanilia, suszone owoce, nuta whisky. I to również w smaku, kawa i gorzka czekolada, finisz długi taniczny. Nasycenie niemal płaskie.

Butelka. Barwa praktycznie czarna nieprzejrzysta. Piany brak. Aromat na pierwszy niuch przypominający portera. Dużo ciemnych słodów, kawa, lekka czekolada. Po ogrzaniu dają o sobie znać nuty mokrego drewna, whisky w postaci torfu i popiołowości. W smaku lekka słodycz. Delikatne nuty whisky, kawa. Na drugim planie pojawia się bardzo przyjemna niezalegająca nuta torfowa. Wysycenie niskie tak jak i goryczka. Konsystencja mało lepka, ale napewno nie wodnista. Bardzo ciekawe piwo, które zmienia się szybko pod wpływem ogrzewania się. Jestem ciekaw jak wypadają pozostałe wersje.

Fra flaske på Mi2, Cardinal (Asko Rogaland ølmesse): brunsvart, ok skum. Mmm... et lekkert preg fra fatlagringen - torvrøyk, svisker, vanilje og en knivsodd salt, med litt lakris helt i slutten. Lekre saker for snille gutter.

Shared bottle at Mi2 Extended at Cardinal 06.06.16. Reddish ebony. Small, brown head. Fine aroma of Scottish Whisky, sweet dark malt, dates and prunes - balanced with moderate bitterness. Ripe prunes in aftertaste.

330 ml bottle. Really dark brown with a minimal beige head. Aroma has roasted malt, coffee, vanilla, dark chocolate and alcohol. Taste is sweet, long, bitter, malty(roasted), peat/smoke. Low carbonation and medium/full body. Long bitter finish with burned tires.

Bottle from June 2014. Pours a dark brown with a medium tan head. Roasted malts on the nose along with chocolate, vanilla, cocoa and molasses. Taste is light sweet with a moderate frutyness. Some bready maltyness, a bit of whiskey and a long sweet finish.

Aroma: roasted dark malts, bitter chocolate, peated.
Appearance: black color and beige head.
Taste: low herbal bitterness, bitter chocolate, peated, bonfire, smoked notes, burnt malt, quite dry.
Palate: medium body and medium carbonation, peated finish.
Overall: It is a really good stuff, amazing peated notes, smooth and complex.

330 ml bottle. Black color with small brown head. Malty aroma, roasted, dark dried fruits, chocolate, milk chocolate, cocoa, vanilla, licorice, smoked notes, wood. Sweet and light bitter taste like aroma, chocolate, smoked notes, fruits and vanilla. Medium oily body with soft carbonation.

Bottle from Brew Bristol.
Appearance: black colour, small dark head which dissapers slowly, fair lacing.
Aroma: malts - vanila, dark chocolate, coffee, caramel. A little bit of burnt tyre after a while. 
Taste: very nicely sweet, long duration.
Palate: full bodied, thick, oily, flat, perfectly balanced.
Very drinkable beer, as for 8% very light, superb balance.

330ml bottle served in snifter glass. Purchased at Drinks of the World - Geveva.
A: Pours a oil black color forming a medium dark beige head with medium to low retention and only few spotty lacings left in the glass.
S: Great nose. Sweet caramel, roasted malts, whisky and wood. Vanilla and licorice. Light notes of leather and earth.
T: Sweet upfront taste. Strong notes of roasted malts, whisky and oak. Notes of vanilla and licorice. In overall, the taste is sweet and slightly bitter. Light notes of grassy hops.
M: Heavy body. Medium to low carbonation. Sweet caramel, whisky and oak in the aftertaste.
O: Excellent drinkability. Classic British Old Ale.

Appearance: nearly solid black with only the merest hint of brown around the margins, short beige head, poor retention and no lacing. (3/5) Aroma: whiskey, bakers chocolate, liquorice, vanilla, oak. (7/10) Taste: moderate sweet, moderate bitter, light alcohol. (7/10) Palate: full slightly oily body, moderate-low carbonation, off-dry lightly boozy finish. (4/5)

Somewhat to my surprise, I half think this really did have a best before - because this is so mild that the only conclusion I can draw is that its faded in the bottle. On the up side, its extremely mild and easy drinking, with a very mild whiskey character. (14/20)

Bottle @Bir&Fud Bottega (Rome). Pours oily black with a minimal head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, licorice, smoked notes. Flavour is medium sweet with a good bitter end and a smoked note. High body, medium to light carbonation. It didnt age well...

Bottle with the Belgrade Boys at Halloween tasting. Same dark pour as the other OEOs. Richer, more complex barrel. Body of the beer is less developed, more cola. Whiskey-barrel note is better but beer itself has suffered. A little residual sweetness.

Shared 11.2 oz. bottle. Pours dark brown with a dark beige head that quickly subsides. Nose is malt, whisky, oak, and dark fruit sweetness. Taste follows; with a roasted malt component and bitter chocolate notes. Medium body. Pretty good.

Aroma: rich and complex; whiskey faint but not overwhelming like many other barrel aged beers. Appearance: pitch black with off white head that dissipates quickly; little lacing; Taste: malty with more pronounced whiskey flavors (still not overwhelming); complex; excellent; Palate: heavy body with shorter finish than expected; Overall: delicious. Would definitely buy again.

330ml bottle. Pours an opaque dark brown, almost black with a small, short lived, light brown head that laces. Aroma of roasted malt, smoke, coffee, oak and whisky. Sweet flavour of roasted malt, dark chocolate, licorice, coffee, smoke, whisky and oak with a dry, mildly bitter finish. Medium body with a creamy, smooth, oily texture and soft carbonation. Very nice.
Black with brown head. Oak, spicy, vanilla and herbal. Sweet, dry and woody finish. Overall: good! 18 og 12 is better.
Svart med lavt lys brunt skum. Lukter godt fatlagringen, eik, nøtter og noe sjokolade. Fyldig. Søtlig start, svisker og vanilje. Utover kommer en nøtteaktig avslutning. Noe alkohol i avslutningen.

Bottle 0.33l at The Halloween tasting 2015 Belgrade Serbia.Taste at Beerville Bar with our small tasting group.Bro Vlada, Bro Alberto and Bro Matt.Bottle from the Great British festival.Pour it dark color with small white head.Aroma of roasted malt.Taste of vanilla again, whiskey flavour, not comlexed and balanced like other two 12 and 21.Flat finish little bit.
Tasting at my place. Bottle shared thanks to Mrk. Black. Coffee, dark chocolate, marzipan, whisky. Sweet with bitter finish. Interesting development of palate. Backlog from 2015/01/09.
Bouteille #13650. Un liquide brun foncé avec une mousse beige. Un nez de cuir, vanille, touche de chocolat. Une bouche agréable, facile mais oh combien efficace et savoureuse. Très bon.
2012 Bottle. Black color, brown head. Aroma has licorice, oak barrels, wet wood, chocolate. Smooth palate, oak, chocolate, coffee. Very smooth, aged nicely.

Bottle; pours black with a thin tan head; aroma of malt, wood, scotch, and hints of chocolate and dark fruits; taste is malty with chocolate and dark fruits plus hints of wood; finish is light bitter with hints of chocolate and wood; good beer

Chocolate, smoke, toasted biscuits, peat, soy sauce, some roasted notes, and a bit of raisins in the nose, as well as the ever-growing presence of alcohol. It is more restrained and less messy than I was hoping for. The mouthfeel is medium, a bit sticky but not very viscous, with prickly carbonation. The taste is chocolatey bitter, slight molasses sweet, and a woody/boozy tanginess toward the end, for a dry, cerealy finish. Very palatable, if a little too safe.

(Harviestoun Ola Dubh (16 Year Old)) Bottle 330 ml at home, served into a snifter. ABV 8%
Pitch black colour on the body, small bubbles and a bit of foam around the glass.
Strong whiskey notes on the aroma, chocolate, prunes.
Taste of roasted malts, iodium, strong whiskey notes, light chocolate, coal, mildly sweet.
Medium body, soft carbonation.
Very good, much more whiskey than the 12 years edition.

Bottle No & Date: 13683, MAY 2014. Arômes et saveurs de cuir, de tabac, de whiskey, de délicate fumée, de fruits, de charbon de bois, de vanille, de malts doux. Corps moyen et texture soyeuse. Finale sèche par la fumée et le bois calciné. Complexe. Complètement délicieuse.

At the Belgrade-Serbia tasting on 31/10/2015. Many thanks markoijelena for sharing this bottle. Pours black with a minimal ivory foam lowering super fast. Nose: a bit anonymous but still quite nice. Whiskey far away, a bit of vanilla but not a blast. Mouth: too much alcohol, not rich, more cola. Nice but not stunning.
Bottle pour at Pai Men in Portland Maine. Thin ring of white head. Boozy scotch and cocoa aroma. Scotch, sweet, molasses , vanilla and chocolate taste. Big and rich.

33cl bottle. Opaque black colour with a small tan head. Wood, vanilla, licorice, light roasted and smoke in the aroma. Soft carbonation and medium body. Taste is balanced with some wood notes. Overall, a good beer.

Black color with nice tan head. Slightly peaty aroma, wood, some prunes. Taste is malty, dark fruits, slightly peaty, low but present carbonation. Superbly balanced, so good. Way better than the 12yo.
Donker rood bruin bier met een goede beige schuim kraag. Ruikt zoet, alcohol, geroosterd, spek, siroop. Smaakt wat zoeter dan de 12, siroop, vanille, dunnig.
Mooie zwarte kleur met een kleine kraag. Ruikt zoetig, vanille, crèmebrulee. Smaakt zoetig, vanille, beetje koffie. Beetje dun. Minder dan de 12.

Flavour is sweet with burned malts, whisky and oak barrels, as well as muscovado and dark fruits, and with a lingering sweetly finish.

Aroma of sweet raisins, prunes, coffee, smoke/peat. Smoky flavor with notes of coffee, burnt malts, brown sugar, dried fruits, leather. UPDATED: FEB 17, 2014 Dark cherries, dark chocolate, wood, smooth vanilla, toasted bread, whiskey and raisins. Hints of caramel, licorice and clove. Bite of alcohol at the end but great texture carries it well.

12 oz bottle. Poured an dark mahogany when put up my flashlight app, otherwise looks jet black. Thin khaki head. Complex taste of roasted and toasted malts, followed by the boozy barrel flavor, and vanilla eaters. Medium carbonation, smooth creamy thick body. Wow, damn good beer!
12oz bottle pours a dark black with a thin brown head. Whiskey barrel and chocolate aroma. Taste is the same.

Drinkability baja y espuma inexistente. Sacando eso el sabor, aroma y paladar son excelentes. Hay café, tostado, ahumado, chocolate, retroamargor de café y lúpulo, y el whisky! Se siente desde el aroma hasta el final del trago. Muy buena!!!

Bottle pour black with almost no head and no lacing. Smoky whisky aroma. Taste is smoky charred oak with chocolate and whisky, and it sweetens a bit as the brew warms. Medium mouthfeel but almost flat. Bittersweet finish.

330 ml bottle into tulip glass, bottled in 7/2011. Pours nearly opaque dark brown color with a small dense khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a thin lace cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass. Aromas of dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, brown sugar, raisin, peat smoke, wood, tobacco, leather, toast, light vanilla, and roasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with good balance and deep complexity of dark/roasted malt and barrel notes; with good strength. Taste of dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, brown sugar, raisin, peat smoke, wood, tobacco, leather, toast, dark bread, vanilla, light clove, and roasted earthiness. Lingering notes of chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, brown sugar, raisin, peat smoke, wood, toast, tobacco, dark bread, and roasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Very nice flavors with deep complexity and great balance of dark/roasted malt and scotch barrel flavors; with zero cloying flavors after the finish. Light-medium carbonation and medium bodied; with a moderately creamy, smooth, and slightly chalky mouthfeel that is good. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming present after the finish. Overall this is an excellent barrel aged old ale. All around great complexity and balance of dark/roasted malt and scotch barrel flavors; and very smooth to sip on. A very enjoyable offering.

Pours ink black to reddish with little to no head, a bit cloudy on the top. Aroma is strong and pleasing but not that uncommon in similar beers. Tastes of roasted coffee, powerful, lasting feeling on the palate, smokey, the complex taste evolves in mouth for quite a long time to leave a bittersweet afternote.

One of the best beers Ive ever had. Makes me think of the petrol that would propell Gods motorized chariot.
Interesting. Has an unusual toasty aroma with notes that I can't quite place. Maybe licorice? Flavor is similar. Has a dry finish with a lil more unusualness that I can taste in my nose.

En bouche, la contribution du fût de scotch est à lavant-plan, avec des notes de tourbe, diode et de fumée. On retrouve également une belle base maltée et chocolatée, riche sans être sucrée. Finale relativement mince et lalcool est tout à fait absent. Intéressant pour les amateurs de scotch.

Its pitch black in color, but thin in appearance, with a weak head. The nose is more smoky than reminiscent of whiskey, with that dirty engine oil-like roast malt and peat aroma forming the basis of the nose. I think the Ola Dubh 12 year old smells a little more luscious. In the mouth its very meaty, like a barbecued sirloin doused with a healthy amount of black pepper. It is pretty thin in the mouth, with ghostly hints of sticky whisky sweetness and alcohol, but all packed in a relatively low alcohol beer. 

Its a little weak in potency, and with smoke character really wants me to bathe in more of it, but its a little too timid and its pretty frustrating. I love its character, but I want more of it. Its definitely more mellow than the 12 year old version, but still very respectable.

ubh (or Black Oil) is a collaboration between Harviestoun Brewery and Highland Park, Distiller of the Year*. It is based on Harviestouns award-winning Old Engine Oil. With more than a stylistic nod to the classic Imperial Porters (and Stouts) of the nineteenth century, this deliciously rich, dark, 8% a.b.v. beer is the first ale to be aged in malt whisky casks from a named distillery and, with traceable casks and numbered bottles, the rest with genuine provenance. Ola Dubh will initially be available in three different expressions; the initial release will be of small batches aged in casks formerly used to mature Highland Park 12 Year Old, Highland Park 16 Year Old and Highland Park 30 Year Old. Further variants are planned for the future. Ola Dubh is, in the words of beer afficionado Owen D.L. Barstow: The most interesting new British beer I have tried in years.

AROMA: coffee, licorice, toast, roasty, 
APPEARANCE: black, minimal head, brown foam, 
TASTE: medium bitterness, umami, light sweetness, 
PALATE: medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, bitter, long finish, sticky on the lips
OVERALL: very rounded aromas that all complement, incredibly long aftertaste of licorice and bitternes.

You look at this beer and try to discern a colour... the best you can get is that it is as black as sin and maybe shows some mahogany around the dimple and the rim of the glass.  The head upped and went after a very short time leaving a herbal-greenish tinge on a latte skim of bubble. The nose is just molasses all over. Im surprised this s connected with whisky and not dark rum. Black strap molasses, pumpernickel, rye, dark chocolate, treacle, plums and thick plastic dominate the aromas. While it is obviously enormous, it is a treat for the nose. Thick and oily in the mouth, those aroma signatures abound in the mouth with plentiful molasses. There is a nod toward bitterness but the start is its thick, oily texture. It is chewy and reminds me of an acquaintance who having been to Ireland (and was not known as a Guinness drinker) said you could stand a spoon up in the pints. This is probably as close as that gets. A bit of bonfire smoke starts to come out in the flavour, which is gratifying and resonates with the house character of Highland Park whisky - also a favourite.
This is love: beer and whisky in poetic harmony. Sweet toward the finish without being sickly and cloying. Plenty of lingering warmth in the top of the chest and a platoon of Orcadian distillery workers and Caledonian brewers to thank. The warmth in my chest is probably made up just as much of love.

330ml bottle (Alko Arkadia, Helsinki)
Very gentle dry dusty smoky aroma, only a hint of whisky, but more so as it warms. Lovely smooth palate, gentle carbonation. Retronasals beautiful, a little oaky and buttery, but again not really saying whisky to me. Yet more proof that these guys are Scotlands best brewery, by far.

4.5 S: Massive nose on this. Whiskey is still quite potent. Smoke and roastiness compete for center stage, but ultimately the smoke wins out and adds a pleasant porcine component. Caramel, molasses, and notes of chocolate and toffee. Plum, raisin, and red apple fruitiness. Light peat.

Whiskey...
...roasted, coffee and chocolate. Very smooth but a bit on the thin side and low carbonation. Tastewise this is really delicious. Thank you, Erik:)

Bottle from Vinmonopolet. Pours pitch black with a big creamy tanned head. Aroma of wood,port and vanilla. Taste is more in the same direction, but with more good stuff like liquorice, coffee and dark chocolate. Smooth mouthfeel, round and vinous. Good stuff.

Bottle. Black with a light tan head. Aroma of toffee, chocolate, plums, sherry, peat, tar. Um, oily mouthfeel. Taste is sweet and medicinal, with toast, chocolate, dark fruits and wood. The whisky flavours are much better integrated into the beer than in the 12yo version but are still a little overbearing, particularly in the medicinal notes. Enjoyed this, but again, a little less than Old Engine Oil.

Bouteille 330ml.  De couleur brune très foncée et quasi-opaque. Nez de malt rôti, fruité (prunes noires, notes de raisins, traces de figues), moyen-léger de réglisse noire, léger de vanille et de chocolat noir, légèrement boisé (fût de chêne) avec des notes dalcool (whisky) et de café. Moyenne-ronde en bouche avec un pétillement bas ainsi quune texture riche, huileuse et légèrement crémeuse. Goût légèrement fruité (prunes, notes de raisins, faibles traces de figues) accompagné dun moyen goût de vanille et  dun léger goût de réglisse noire lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute rapidement un goût de malt rôti, un léger goût de chocolat noir avec des traces de mélasse brûlée puis à mesure que la finale approche, un goût dalcool très doux (whisky), légèrement réchauffant et boisé (fût de whisky) vient sinstaller avec de faibles traces de café et de noix grillées. Post-goût long, légèrement amer dalcool doux et de rôti avec un léger goût fruité (pelures de prunes, notes de moût de raisins), un léger goût boisé et de faibles notes de chocolat noir.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2011 11.2 oz. bottle, pours a deep dark brown / black with a small tan head. Aroma of wood, dark fruits, light whiskey, and roasted malts. Flavour is slightly sweeter than the 12 and 18, with sweetened dark fruits and vanilla, meshing beautifully with the wood, whiskey and big roastiness. Excellent, but I prefer the 12 and 18 due to the more pronounced sweetness in this one.

Medium sized tan head black pour mild medium carbonation aromas earthy dark fruit liquorice not strong aromas alcohol overtone whiskey flavours the whiskey plum peaty note liquorice yeast vanilla light fizz and resin good bitter from the malts salty taste finish peaty whiskey dark fruit and malts flavours come through eventually after weak aromas good aftertaste whiskey light salty bitter fruit vanilla

aged in 16 yr old single malt scotch whisky casks, individually numbered and dated on the bottle (#16611, Aug 2010). Pours with less head than the 12yr, noticeably a more aggressive front: smokier, more bitter, less chocolate, more dark roasted coffee, less sweet. If the 12 yr is a 65% cacao, this is more like a 75% or even 80%. The bitterness subdues the sweetness. Overall, heavier than the 12yr but still remarkable.

Bottle. Pours a near-black deep brown body with a small off-white head. Nose is licorice, wood, honey, deep roasted malts and hints of whisky. Taste is whisky and hints of alcohol up front, giving a bit of a burning sensation. Then, the palate fades down a bit, picking up caramel, licorice and honey tones. A roasty finish with considerable bitterness; hints of burnt toast, wood and whisky ends each sip. Thick and viscous palate, which I find suitable for such a beer. A very nice old ale from Harviestoun.

11.2 oz. bottle, bottled in july 2009, second of four (12, 16, 30 and 40)- Pours black as black with a tan creamy head that recedes quickly to a collar. Aroma is lighter on the whiskey and heavier on the oak, or at least the oak is more prominent since the whiskey is less in your face, still very rich. The flavor is bitter sweet chocolate and oak, but again the whiskey is much more subdued, interesting. I think I like this one better, I am not the biggest whiskey fan, and I like it in my beers, when its subtle, but some beers over do it, this is not one of them. Body is again thick as oil, carbonation is again low, nice beer. Next up, the 30, cant wait.

33 cl bottle, BBE 201Z (sic!), bottled JAN 2009. Rated on 24.6.2011
Tasting of all Ola Dubh versions from 12 to 40 and Old Engine Oil as a reference. This was the worst Dubh with 40.
Aroma has lots of more vanilla than 12. It is not as pungent or peated but also lighter. Some liqorice also exists in the aroma. Flavour is a bit weird, light and contains some harsh bitterness too. Liqorice can be observed when the beer warms up, but unfortunately some soy sauce comes too. Still good stuff anyway.
Color pitch black, smell pretty nice. Soft taste, great carbonation and body, very well balanced. Nice long finish. Very nice beer.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2012 Bottle from Alko Arkadia. Originally rated on 12.4.2009. One of the finest barrel aged beers. Best of the series IMO. 10-4-9-5-18 = 4.6

Re-rated @ 6.3.2012. 330ml bottle @ Gloria, Kuopio. BBE Jan 2012 - Pours pitch black with a nice small and sticky light brown head. Massive and strong aroma of whisky notes, oak, vanilla, roasted malts and ash. Magnificently well balanced taste of lightly roasted malts, vanilla, oak and lovely whisky notes. Finish is roasty with slight whisky notes. Some hints of age as well. Full bodied, but smooth and oily texture. Perhaps this is slightly better fresh but still a great barrel aged beer.

Bottle.  Aroma has notes of bourbon, smoke, oak, coffee, roasted malts, charcoal, and sweet molasses.  Black hue with a small tan head that left some lace.  Flavor is med sweet and bitter.  Palate is medium bodied and oily soft.  Overall a nice bourbon infused ale.  Well balanced and the smoke really worked. Nice.

Bottle. 41145 July 2009.  Dark black pour with quickly disappearing mocha head.  Chocolate, nuts, oak, acidic smell, cocoa, leather.  Smooth and not too powerful.  A beer to sip and relax.  I am not if this will improve with age (and if not, this is a bit over priced).

From Voldby, DK.
Bottled, 220511.
Black with brown head. Aroma of malt and roast. Flavor with chocolate and spices.

Pours an expected motor oil black with a short lived beige cap. The aroma is awesome, just like the other years, big on molasses, anise, cherry, smoke, peat, jerky, chocolate, awesome, this all the dubhs are really about the nose. The flavour is all things roasty, smoke, cocoa, beef jerky, anise. Finish is dry, with notes of oak. Awesome beer, too expensive though.

13/06/2011 bottle @ Klaas place - bottled 9/2009, BB: 9/2012(2011-264)  Thanks to Klaas for sharing the bottle!
Very dark brown to black beer, beige small head, unstable, little adhesive. Aroma: mocha, dark chocolate, coffee, brown sugar. MF: very little carbon, full body, bit oily texture. Taste: caramel, sweet malts, sugar, bit sour, fruity, dark chocolate. Aftertaste: sweet caramel, mocha, more dark chocolate.

Har lite mer porter än whiskey doft jämfört med sina äldre bröder.

Ganska tunn vätska, smak av kaffe, laktriz och choklad.

Bottle shared by Mike, thanks 
Appearance: Almost black with a medium sized beige head and some lacing 
Aroma: Roasted malts, dark fruit, dry cocoa and whiskey 
Taste: Roasty, cocoa, coffee, woody and whiskey 
Very nice and enjoyable
This one wasnt too different from the 12 years old one. It got the exact same score. Pitch black. Earth-like smell.

Single bottle purchased from Kensington Wine Market in Calgary, AB on 06/02/2011. Colour: As expected, black with light brown thickish medium-low height head. Nose: Oak with first vapours but quickly turns to mild engine oil. Some rich dark bread (pumpernickel?) comes into play after swirling and a surge of peat smoke finishes things off. Taste: Medium sweet, light sour, medium bitter. A touch sweeter than I expected but nothing offensive. Smoke is more dominant than it was in the nose, and the oak isnt as present as it was. A slight seafoody-like salty taste and a repeating blast of peat smoke comprise the finish. Palate lines decently but is thin in the body.
Bottled. Chocolate powder and whiskey in the nose. Complex. Smooth. Medium to full bodied. Caramel and heather sneaking in. A beer with a lot of character.

330ml bottle 
8.0% ABV 
Best Before: August 2013 
This is Review #600.  Yay me! I tried this beer on March 8, 2011 after purchasing from the Queens Quay LCBO outlet in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer poured a solid black colour with a long lasting light brown head.  The aroma was roasted malt, vanilla, and nuts.  The mouthfeel was full bodied, and creamy.  The flavour was roasted malt, smoke, and coffee.  The whisky appears in the finish.

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2014 ***rerate oct22, 14 - smooth and slighly dry, zero alcohol until the back end of the aftertaste, the taste is there that I want but its super mellow. I really want to love this with high marks but cant do it as it just wont allow full flavor. Its a chugger needs to be sipped****Super black with a pinkie thick medium brown creamy cap. A small head remains throughout. Smooth and soft aroma of dark chocolate, roasted malts, fruit, smallest hint of smoke, some sweetness, a bit of vanilla and golden raisins, coconut and faint cherry? Tasty chocolate, a touch of alcohol, burnt malts, vanilla, faint fruit, somehow this beer is dulling my ability to think. Licorice, light oak, good malts and chocolate but not much else... this is a bit boring. Near to full bodied, fairly smooth but the alcohol and a hard burntness keeps this less smooth than I hoped. Long finish. 3.5

Pours okay, plopping into the pint and spreading out in a sludgy trudge (good band name there.)  Smells like a bourbon-shaded oak-tinged malty chocolate eclair floating in a pool of molasses.  Or something thereabouts.  The first taste is strange, since, thanks to the beers black-as-night color, youre expecting something along the lines of a stout.  But Ola Dubh is a true old ale, tasting of glazed doughnuts and rich caramel.  Slowly gains a peat-infused center, before delving into the gloriously boozy depths of 16 year old Scotch.  The texture is as smooth as warm milk, causing fuzziness with alarming alacrity.  (3/19/09)

Bottle I picked up in Orlando over the weekend. Dark brown pour with a thin head and spotty lacing. Aroma was malty with hints of fudge and oak. Flavor was a bit soy saucy with malts and chocolate on the back end. A good beer but I guess I was expecting a little  bit more booziness.

Nicely poured into a tulip glass, this beer was attractively dark. The head was thin, tan and creamy, which was followed by some messy lacing. The smell was definitely of a sour whiskey, spicy and smokey with a hint of vanilla. Flavors were impressive, wasnt as strong as the scent but otherwise satisfying. Molasses with a good bbq smokiness arouse the palette. This is then followed by a gradual latter of delectable undertones like a good scotch, woody too. This beer was a real treat, and is meant to be savored, not because of the high ABV but rather because its just so damn delicious. You will want more than one.
Thick, rich roasty chocolate malt profile with scotch whiskey smoothness.  Anise, a little soy sauce, mild vanillin.  Not really any discernible alcohol note.  Good beer.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2011 Nice pick up from Knightly Spirits. Tulip. The nose was quite pleasant. Sour whiskey notes and smokiness from the aging shone through quite strongly. The look of this beer was nice with dark, oil-like color and mouth feel and a beige, sticky head and lacing. The taste had two dominant flavors that came through: smoked bacon and BBQ sauce. A light whiskey sour/bitterness was also present. Good beer but not something to have everyday. More like a special occasion beer.
33 Bottle in Klooster, shared. Both the whiskey smell and flavor is far more subdued in the 16 year than the 30 but still an excellent beer.

Taken from notes. Got to try this alongside a glass of Glenfiddich 18 Year Single-Malt Scotch Whiskey, and it really pairs well with this! Pours motor oil black with a small, tan head that dissipates to nothing in no time. Aroma is heavy scotch whiskey, dark chocolate, peat, and a little vanilla. Flavor is much of the same. Huge hits of scotch whiskey booziness along with subtle notes of chocolate, roasted malts, and smokiness. Mouthfeel isnt as thick as I thought itd be, but still very good. Any chance of tasting subtle, lingering flavors in the finish are pulverized by a strong whiskey heat. Overall, very interesting brew. Not mind-blowing or anything. In fact, I think the unique flavors were over-powered by the massive booziness. Still, the experience of drinking it on Thanksgiving with a good friend and a good glass of scotch whiskey made it all the better :-) Reviewed on 11/25/2010

I like an old Ale and this one is no exception. I seen it sitting on the selves but never pulled the plug on buying one, my mistake. I sat on the bottle for a year and when I cracked it open I got a slight hiss of carbonation so I got a little bit of a tan head in the pour. The body was black in color. The brew was light bodied or to say thin in the viscosity department. You get a ton of peat in the nose but so the barrel did its job. Flavor wise more of the same good scotch notes oak and peat with a touch of smoke. Vanilla showed up as well as a touch of sweetness from the malts. its a great brew a tad pricey but worth the coin. I would buy one on my own after trying this one.

330 ml bottle from LCBO (side-by-side with 18 and 30).  Pours a very dark, opaque brown with modest-sized tan head.  Aroma is chocolate, brown sugar, light roast and whiskey/oak.  Flavour starts with cocoa and light bwon sugar with the whiskey/oak taste from the cask coming through towards the end.  Thinner than I might have anticipated, but decent body all the same.  Didnt find huge differences between the three - this one had a little less oaky/whiskey flavour and maybe a little less pizzaz over all.  Still quite nice.

Bouteille de 330 ml achetée chez LCBO (Ottawa, ONT). Arôme: Odeur de chocolat avec une pointe dalcool. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Saveur: Goût de chocolat avec une pointe de vanille et de petits fruits. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement vineuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence dalcool en arrière goût. (Rating #3609)

Reviewed from notes.

Served in a tulip glass. Pours a very dark brown color with a thin tan head. A bit of legs on the side of the glass. The nose is whisky, oak, light vanilla, caramel, roasted malt, and a bit of dark fruits. The taste is a bit less complex with a tad bit of oak and some light whisky character. Really nice feel that captures all the elements well. Drinks nicely and is a solid sipper.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-14-2010

330ml bottle from the lcbo. pours deep brown with a small tan head. big barrel and whiskey nose. nice flavours of the base beer with nicely integrated barrell contribution. pretty good but not great overall. the 12 is still the star of the ola dubh franchise.

very dark w/ fizzy head
roasted malt and oaky aroma
really nice treakle and oak flavour. nicer than the 12yo. this is hardly fizzy so it is thick and rich. really great!

Its hard to avoid the intense aroma, which I could smell as I was pouring it. Although this beer has a bit of body, I can picture myself drinking it on a hot day. Very enjoyable, but not as good as some other "whiskey barreled" brews Ive sampled.
(bottle)  Stoutragious pick for the week.  Roasted coffee with imparted oak and whisky flavors.
nice Harvieston effort thanks to Quez for the pick of the week - used motor oil color with minimal head - whisky flavor makes this a great sipper for me

Deep black colour. Tan head slowly dissipating. Rich fruit berry aroma with hints of whisky. Lovely rich flavour, liquorice, winter berries with hints of chocolate. whisky finish. Finishes of with the heat of a dram.
Bottle.  Black with thin tan head.  Aroma is whisky and some roasted chocolate.  Very nice.

Pours like motor oil with a very thin head. Aroma has lots of peet moss notes as you would expect from the barrel aging. Nice smooth mouthfeel though a bit thinner than expected. A bit of hoppiness but flattened by the malts. Lingers nicely afterwards.

Bottle from Alexander Wines, Coventry. Pours thick and tarry with a low tan foam. Aroma of grilled aubergine, ink, beef stock and squashy dried fruit (prunes) dusted with drinking chocolate. Lovely meaty, well-oaked dark beer oozing with smoked meat, well-roasted Med veg, chocolate and dried fruit notes. Full, black porridge thickness; the custard of oak, burnt chocolate cake, kippers, sprig of mint (singed). Sweet cigar linger. Beer of distinguished, quiet power.

Pours pitch back with a super thin tan head.  Nose of wisky, oak, and malt.  Taste was wisky, caramel, and oak.  I am a big Highland Park Scotch guy and I was really looking forward to trying this.  I felt it was a little thin when compared to BCS and then I figured out it isnt a stout and that explained it.  A very tasty treat in any event.

Bottle. Pours semi-opaque black, thin off-white head, lacing is spotty to poor. Nose is restrained whiskey, dark fruit, light mocha. Flavours of tart whiskey and berries, some stylish whiskey notes, along with some roast malt. The least impressive of the Ola Dubh series.

11.02.2011. 0,33l Bottle. Edinbourgh. Dark brown or black colour with brown head. Dense malty aroma. Rich beer with full body. Yhere is swetness, bitterness and whiskey flavours. Very good malty flavours. Aftertaste is sweet malty with notesof roasted whiskey.

$9 for 11.2oz bottle
Bottled Sept 2007 Sampled Nov 2008

A vigorous pour coaxes a thin tan head out of this solid black beer. The head dissipates quickly. Heavy aroma of vanilla some roasted malts, dark chocolate and some scotch. Taste is chocolate and roasted malts, faint scotch and ash. Lingering roasted malt bitterness in the finish. Mouthfeel is creamy smooth. Body is medium Carbonation is adequate. Great smelling and tasting brew. I would have liked the body a bit thicker, but great just the same. Subtle, not over whiskeyd. This one seemed smoother and creamier than the 12. Both great though.

12 oz bottle served in a tulip, courtesy of Daknole, THANKS!!   Pour is motor oil with just the smallest wisp of beige head floating on top.  Nose is roasted malt, scotch, peat, barn lumber, dark fruits, must, and hay.  Taste is similar, but in a much more mild, watered down fashion.  The body is amazingly light and drinkable, considering the viscosity and nose.  I love bourbon aged brews, but havent fallen in love with whisky cask stuff.  However, of the brews Ive sampled, this is the best to date.

pours cream black with good lace and a tan coloured head. aromas are rich and almost peaty, smoke and all sorts of chocolate notes. beautiful
more peat on the palate, some boozy notes and man oh man rich beautiful brew

33 cl bottle, Sheffield, UK via The Dram Shop. Maddies first birthday. Deep brown verging on pith black, Espresso-like head. Balanced coffee and whisky aroma, lighter body than expected. Smooth, mild with a nice velvety finish. More subdued than anticipated but enjoyable.

Black pour with a small brown head.  Aroma was great notes of whiskey and wood, lots of wood.  Great whiskey.  Light roast.  Flavors were woody and whiskey forward with a light roasty finish.  Bitterness was light and welcoming.  Lots of whiskey up front, like a light scotch.  Not much to this one, a bit one dimensional but quite good.  Mouthfeel was a bit thin which docked it a few points here and there.  Good stuff all around though.

330ml bottle. Pours jet black...it may actually absorb light, with a chocolate milk head that leaves a nice little lace. Nose of....Highland Park whiskey but seems to be lacking any beer character. Maybe my nose is just on the fritz but it really just smells like light scotch. No, theres some definite espresso character hiding way down there. Redeems itself in the mouth in a huge way with layers of scotch, coffee, dark chocolate and even some evident hop character with an unusual sweetness in the finish I cant put a label on that mingles well with that scotchy feel.

330ml bottle from the LCBO. Pours an oily, flat-looking black colour with some large bubbles clinging to the edges of the glass. The aroma is very rich and sweet with definitive notes of smoke, chocolate, dried fruits, and caramelized sugar, coffee and oak. The flavour has a very distinctive scotch presence with loads of smokey goodness that are noticeable instantaneously. There are sweet flavours of chocolate, cocoa and some dried fruits, though much less than in the aroma. The hints of smoke linger the longest in the finish. Very good.

I absolutely love this beer. The pour is deep opaque black with a thick dark head. Aromas of smoke, peat, roasted malts, chocolate and coffee are all present. The taste is smooth and intense with a moderate scotch smokey taste on the finish. I love everything about this beer.

330ml bottle, pitch black color, with a small tan-colored head, mild roasted, chocolate malt, chocolatey palines nose, with a light cocoa powder, burnt fruitcake, dark bitter chocolate, molasses accent, and some faint coffee, earthy peated smoked malt notes in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a mild earthy roasted, chocolate, black, peated malt, dark bitter chocolate character, with some chocolate ice cream, roasted coffee beans, burnt toast, burnt fruitcake character with some faint flowery leafy, grassy hop flavours and some black coffee, light tobacco leaf undertones, leading towards a dark bitter chocolate,earthy peated tobacco leaf, roasty bitterness finish.

330 ml bottle from LCBO, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. BB SEP 2012. 
App.:  Deep brown-black with a nice light mocha head.
  
Aroma:  Rich dark chocolate with some definite vinous fruit notes, molasses, a bit of licorice, inky darkness, some minty/cola herbals, a bit of integrated peaty smoke, vanilla, more rich chocolate, really nice.
  
Palate:  Medium+body, smooth, sparse effervescence.
  
Flav.:  The smoke is more assertive and peatier, a touch phenolic?, the malts are there, but note as playful or complex as in the nose, less chocolate, more molasses, a bit of vague fruitiness, more peat smoke, a bit of licorice, decent; slightly off-dry with some bitterness and an inky, smoky finish that lingers with some molasses.

I wont bother trying to compare these vertically.  I really enjoyed the nose but was a little disappointed by the flavour.  Overall, still quite enjoyable.

Rich black color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, oak, coffee, vanilla, & dark fruit; Flavor of roasted smoky malt, coffee, dark fruit, molasses, dark chocolate, some vanilla, and hops; Finish is smooth; Very nicely balanced; Overall, nice whiskey qualities - excellent brew.

Bottle, from trade with Papsoe. An oily and quite flat beer, black body and a small tan head on top. The aroma is smoother than for the 12 years, with the same lightly peated whiskey alcohol and roasted malts. Sweet as the 12 year, but more peaty. Equally warming, oily and full-bodied. Roasted, bitter and peated finish. Definitely nice, a typical 1 hour beer, but Im not blown away by it. 100827
Bottle. Black with small beige head. Flavour is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, peat, wood, whiskey and vanilla.

Happy New Year 2011! This is the last of these X year old left for me to rate. Black and thick with a very thin brown head. Strong aroma of smoke, alcohol and molasses. One of the more drinkable versions. Sweet with strong alcohol. Lots of molasses with some chocolate notes and a bit of toffee.

Pours a fairly thick black brown color with a tan head that quickly becomes a foamy ring. Notes of dark chocolate, peat smoke, vanilla, brownies, meaty bacon, and potting soil. Medium thick mouthfeel with a nice finish length.  Nice

Bottle #22953, brewed August 2010. 33 cL from the LCBO courtesy of Rob and Pat, served in a snifter. Pours black with a small light brown head. The head fades slowly to a bare cover but leaves a moderate amount of fine lace. On the nose, there are aromas of whisky, molasses, chocolate, espresso, herbs and cask wood. The flavour is moderately sweet with complex notes of molasses, roasted malts, smooth whisky and a hint of espresso. The flavour is balanced with a good dose of herbal hops. The finish is long, lingering whisky with hops. On the palate, it is full in body with a creamy texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a very nice sweet roasty ale with a whisky accent in the latter half. It has more prominent whisky notes and hops are more favoured than in the 12 year old.  Another very well made beer with a beautiful creamy and elegant body, ample roasted malts and perfectly complementary whisky notes.

Appearance is an opaque black liquid, with a thick frothy brown head. Aroma is skunky and smells of hops and caramel, and smells slightly sour. Palate is thick and oily, minimal carbonation. Taste is quite bitter, a bit of soy sauce, lots of malt, a bit woody. Cant say Im a fan.

Bottle [330ml], No. 22900, AUG 2010. Pours a very dark brown with ruby highlights and an average size semi-lasting frothy light-brown head. Quite oily looking. Aroma: Wow, that smells great! Roasted malt, vanilla, dark fruit, wood, chocolate, some peat and more -- so much going on here, its wonderful. The flavour, which is simply delicious, follows the aroma with roasted malt, vanilla, dark chocolate, dark fruit, peat, wood and also some coffee and toffee. Alcohols well hidden. Medium bodied, oily mouthfeel. An amazing beer, this is barrel-aging done right and a delight to drink.

Pours black with a thick beige head. Strong coffee aroma with subtle notes of oak and whiskey. Smells amazing. Great flavour roasted malts followed by vanilla and the scotch. Finishing in cool roasted coffee and bitter chocolate flavours. This is one hell of a beer.

33cl, Bottle N°21037, at 8%Vol, new exclusive Scottish brew Anno 2008, from Slijterij van Bergen Eindhoven, complex Porter, yet not too heavy, balanced, clear, small head, very good brew, yet expensive!

Bottle 330 ml , bottled in 2009 # 19160 
Aroma:  mature aroma, creamy whiskey nose , mild vanilla , light berry front, some roast at finish. Quiet nice. 8-
Appearance: dark brown with lighter carbonation, Medium light creamy dark beige top.
Flavour and Palate: Medium bodied. Frontal neat barley smoky roast. Quiet dry , ash like. Mellow low carbonation on mid as well. Burnt barley character, Light cask hints. Interesting yet not in great beer category.

330 mL bottle.  (bb Sept 2012).  Same colour and head as the others.  The aroma has more chocolate, and is a little sharper, though.  In a pleasant way.  The wood is there as well, as is a little Scotch.  The flavour is a little rougher around the edges, with wood and alcohol, cocoa powder, and hops.  As with all, the body could be fuller, but its not bad.  To me, this is the most different of the Ola Dubhs Ive tried.

Bottle. Black with a creamy light brown, cappucino-ish head. Aroma: toffee, peat, licorice and soy sauce. Taste: chocolate, vanilla, toffee, cream, liqueur, licorice. Surpisingly light-bodied, very smooth, low carbonation. Overall: very tasty, packed with flavours, but very smooth and drinkable. On the other hand, I think a bigger body and creamier texture would have made it even better.

Pours dark and rich. Nose is liquor-y, malty. Sweet, because of the liquor content. A slightly bitter finish. Smooth, not nearly as peaty as I would have expected. Perhaps a bit of a letdown in terms of looking for that scotch-y goodness, but quite enjoyable.

My fourth foray into the Ola Dubh reserve beers in a quest  to tell them apart.

330cl bottle pours a deep dark light-defying black ale in the chalice. One finger tight frothy brown cap lasts well and laces.

Aroma on this one is not so endowed with a peat smoke tone, its there but a musty oak dried prune tone sits above it.

Ah yes, the peat tastes show up in the flavor, almost as pronounced as older oaked versions. A little lighter on the palate than older version but it has the same complexity with a slightly dryer hoppier finish. This is a good choice for those who cant afford to put many of the more expensive OD reserves (30 or 40 yr) in the cellar. It has the complexity of the more expensive versions with the oaky- peaty-smoky flavors less pronounced but very detectable.

A great oak-aged beer for the price.

330cl bottle from LCBO.   Pours complete black with a tan colored large head.   I get coffee, peat , roasted almonds , very smooth texture, slightly bitter afterward.  After several tastings and swirls in the mouth I can get the scotch from it as well, peaty again.   Can not detect higher abv in taste at all, very smooth.  This is one of best I have tried yet, cant wait to sample the 18 to 40 year varieties.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2012 pours black as night, small but nice crema, little retention. subtle and long-lasting smoke, big maltiness and roastiness. abv well hidden. soft carbonation, silky, full bodied. great brew! should revisit.

Bottle. Hearty looking deep copper, nearly opaque, with a finely bubbled brown head. Aroma is quite brothy, slightly smoky and woody. Flavours of soy sauce, meaty smoke, roast. There is a dusty old wood quality to the finish. Medium-to-full bodied, velvety mouthfeel. Delicious.
